page.title: 01INTRODUCTION
page.content: About 60% of the Stourmouth area was formed by the Medieval reclamation of the Wanstum Channel.Today this land is arable and controlled grassland, drained and irrigated by a complex of dykes joined to the River Stour.It is more or less uninhabited.Some of the remainder is chalk downland, part of the{Isle of Thanet.}The rest (a low one-time island in the Wantsum) includes the village of{East and West {Stourmouth.}The homes of 90% of the population.Land use in entirely arable and grazing.With the mechanisation of farming,the workforce contracted, so that very few people live in the district today.Most houses are country retreats for retired folk or even {weekend cottages.}There is still a sense of community and tradition to found however.Farming is changing with the grubbing out of orchards.
